text:
Thanks for taking the time <@UBS7QANF3> there are some interesting and very valid points in there. Over the years ive seen many instances of people trading with an advantage from reality shows (where the result is known before markets are suspended) right through to football where the money is swept away as a goal is scored.I havent traded football for years so not sure if this goes on.
The system availability is an issue. An outage doesnt affect me that much because of the nature of my strategies but I can see how this hurts you guys now.
The thing is; even as far back as 2000 in the dotcom era, customers were demanding 5 x 9's availability and getting it (under written by SLA's and penalties). Its a very fair point to say that we the clients should receive some form of recompense. I bet their availability would improve then! In these days of superclusters and engineered systems, unplanned outages should almost be a thing of the past.  One of my customers is a global organisation who have only had one outage since 2008. So its not impossible!

elements.text: Thanks for taking the time

Over the years ive seen many instances of people trading with an advantage from reality shows (where the result is known before markets are suspended) right through to football where the money is swept away as a goal is scored.I havent traded football for years so not sure if this goes on.
The system availability is an issue. An outage doesnt affect me that much because of the nature of my strategies but I can see how this hurts you guys now.
The thing is; even as far back as 2000 in the dotcom era, customers were demanding 5 x 9's availability and getting it (under written by SLA's and penalties). Its a very fair point to say that we the clients should receive some form of recompense. I bet their availability would improve then! In these days of superclusters and engineered systems, unplanned outages should almost be a thing of the past.  One of my customers is a global organisation who have only had one outage since 2008. So its not impossible!

text: <@U02343VJJJ0> has joined the channel

A couple more points on the match fixing issue:

1. Saying you won’t void a market for suspected match fixing, only definite match fixing is essentially saying you won’t ever void a market for match fixing. Anything definitive will only come as the result of an investigation by the authorities and probably subject to an appeals process. By the time you have a definitive answer, the money will be long gone. This is why I think they should be voiding markets before they are settled
2. The more I think about it, the worse the optics look of keeping the exchange market open when all other mainstream bookmakers have stopped taking bets. How do you possibly justify that to the authorities? I don’t think you can abdicate the responsibility for preventing your platform being used by organised crime by saying it’s down to users to detect when this is likely to be happening

elements.text: A couple more points on the match fixing issue:

Saying you won’t void a market for suspected match fixing, only definite match fixing is essentially saying you won’t ever void a market for match fixing. Anything definitive will only come as the result of an investigation by the authorities and probably subject to an appeals process. By the time you have a definitive answer, the money will be long gone. This is why I think they should be voiding markets before they are settled

The more I think about it, the worse the optics look of keeping the exchange market open when all other mainstream bookmakers have stopped taking bets. How do you possibly justify that to the authorities? I don’t think you can abdicate the responsibility for preventing your platform being used by organised crime by saying it’s down to users to detect when this is likely to be happening

text: My point is that bookmakers have a tool they can deploy in this situation which is that they can choose to remove the match and void bets placed on it. As exchange users, we cannot do this even if we strongly believe match fixing is taking place. I think Betfair should be more proactive in the most egregious cases to protect their customers in the same way that bookmakers are protected - and to protect themselves!!

elements.text: My point is that bookmakers have a tool they can deploy in this situation which is that they can choose to remove the match and void bets placed on it. As exchange users, we cannot do this even if we strongly believe match fixing is taking place. I think Betfair should be more proactive in the most egregious cases to protect their customers in the same way that bookmakers are protected - and to protect themselves!!

text: To some extent, definitely. For example, excessive amounts matched given the level of the match (e.g. Challenger qualifier vs Grand Slam final). Excessive amounts matched on a derivative market, such as the 1st set winner

text: Is it not troublesome from a legal perspective though if they declare the reason for voiding as suspected match fixing? That way if players ever got wind of it they might have grounds to sue etc? And Betfair would have to declare the reason for voiding otherwise they would be accused of dodgy antics themselves. For what it's worth <@UBS7QANF3> I completely agree with your sentiment buy I can see the difficulty their end.

text: Fair enough. I think they would still run the risk of customer ire though unless they provided evidence of what constituted suspicious activity. You know how paranoid most punters are on Betfair - claims of no delay IP for market makers, claims of certain users getting put to front of the match queue etc. You can almost hear it now because for most punters they like to find external reasons for their losses

text: A flag in the market book is troublesome because often the damage will already have been done (you want existing bets voided, not future bets avoided). It also might encourage _more_ betting as people try to get the right side of the fix
